presentation.title: Coastal flood regulation in Madagascar
presentation.runninghead: Values resulting from natural coastal protection in Madagascar (no flows)
presentation.description: Assessment of potential source, use and sinks related to ecosystem protection of coastal environments in Madagascar. This model does not include real-time ecosystem service flow analysis, as flows require more time to compute than is feasible for estimating on-the-fly.

page.name: Coastal flood regulation assessment
page.title: Introduction
page.description:
This storyline, developed with financial support from the UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre, describes aspects of coastal flood regulation in Madagascar. This island's coastal ecosystems include dunes, coral reefs, seagrass, and mangroves, all of which can play a role in dissipating wind and wave energy generated by coastal storms. Unlike more northerly nations bordering the Indian Ocean, Madagascar is rarely subject to earthquake-generated tsunami waves. However, eastern Madagascar is highly susceptible to tropical storms coming off the southwestern Indian Ocean. Its storms are relatively poorly studied, with limited infrastructure for measuring and modeling storm magnitude and impact versus other tropical storm prone regions in more developed parts of the world (Naeraa and Jury 1998).

The coastal storm protection models used here are intended as a proof-of-concept framework to spatially link: 1) storm wave sources; 2) ecosystem "sinks" that mitigate wave damage; and 3) social groups or assets that are susceptible to harm by coastal flooding. These models use historic storm track, wind speed, and atmospheric pressure data from tropical storms that occurred in a specified region of time. Tropical Storms Daisy, Geralda, and Litanne, three severe storms that made landfall near the port of Toamasina in 1994, are used in the first version of this model, based on availability of information from Naeraa and Jury (1998). The authors modeled aspects of these storms and their attendant storm surges, providing data for calibration of model results. Our model can easily be applied to other historical storm tracks in Madagascar or elsewhere and to simulated future storm tracks or other large wave events, such as tsunamis. These models can also be relatively easily generalized to other parts of the world, as they rely on global datasets for historical storms, coastal ecosystems capable of mitigating storm surges, and lives and property at risk of flood damage.
page.see-also:
Naeraa, M. and M.R. Jury. 1998. Tropical cyclone composite structure and impacts over Eastern Madagascar during January-March 1994. Meteorology and Atmospheric Physics 65: 43-53.
The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding and data support: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Coastal lives at risk
page.title: Coastal lives at risk
page.description: This model considers populations that live in coastal flood zones as the beneficiaries of coastal storm protection. Decile values of populations at risk of coastal flooding is thus identified as the use model and there is no requirement for a probabilistic model. In parts of the world where coastal flood zones have been mapped, we could overlay flood zones and population density to more accurately map lives at risk, rather than using the coarser resolution map shown here.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: CIESIN, Columbia University.
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Coastal property at risk
page.title: Coastal property at risk
page.description:
This model considers economically valuable assets (structures and property) as the beneficiaries of coastal storm protection. Such data are available directly and there is no requirement for a probabilistic model.
Decile values of economic value at risk from coastal storms is published by CIESIN and is used directly.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: CIESIN, Columbia University.
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Wind speed
page.title: Wind speed
page.description:
Wind speed, used to model the storm surge.

Role in models

Wind speed, obtained here from historical storm records, is proportional to the total potential damage inflicted by wind and waves. Storm surge height and trajectory are used in the flow model to quantify the amount of damaging energy reaching coastal populations or assets or prevented from doing so by natural features.

Representation

The data are in physical units of kilometers per hour.

Source

UNEP Division of Early Warning and Assessment Global Resource Information Database.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: UNEP Global Cyclone Tracks Dataset.
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Atmospheric pressure
page.title: Atmospheric pressure
page.description:
Atmospheric pressure, used to model the storm surge.

Role in models

Atmospheric pressure, obtained here from historical storm records, is proportional to the total potential damage inflicted by wind and waves. Storm surge height and trajectory are used in the flow model to quantify the amount of damaging energy reaching coastal populations or assets or prevented from doing so by natural features.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millibars atmospheric pressure.

Source

UNEP Division of Early Warning and Assessment Global Resource Information Database.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: UNEP Global Cyclone Tracks Dataset.
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Bathymetry
page.title: Bathymetry
page.description:
Wind speed, used to model the storm surge.

Role in models

Ocean depth influences storm surge height, with larger waves typically forming over shallower coastal waters. Storm surge height and trajectory are used in the flow model to quantify the amount of damaging energy reaching coastal populations or assets or prevented from doing so by natural features.

Representation

The data are in physical units of meters.

Source

NASA ETOPO-1 Global Relief Model.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: NASA ETOPO-1 Global Relief Model.
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Storm surge
page.title: Storm surge
page.description:
Storm surge height.

Role in models

This map shows results of a Bayesian model estimating the height of a potential storm surge based on wind speed and atmospheric pressure for a historic storm, as well as the ocean depth at a given location. Greater wind speeds, lower atmospheric pressure, and shallower ocean depths are more likely to lead to greater storm surge heights.

Representation

The data are in physical units of meters.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Seagrass
page.title: Seagrass presence
page.description:
The presence of seagrass beds, which can reduce incoming wave energy.

Role in models

Seagrass beds, along with other vegetation and geomorphic features, are valuable in reducing wave energy that could otherwise inflict damage on coastal populations and property. When present, such features are used in the sink model to determine the total potential of the natural environment to mitigate damage inflicted to humans by storms or tsunamis.

Representation

Data are represented as the presence/absence of seagrass beds.

Source

UNEP-WCMC World Atlas of Seagrasses.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: UNEP-WCMC World Atlas of Seagrasses.
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Mangrove presence
page.title: Mangrove presence
page.description:
The presence of mangroves, which can reduce incoming wave energy.

Role in models

Mangroves, along with other vegetation and geomorphic features, are valuable in reducing wave energy that could otherwise inflict damage on coastal populations and property. When present, such features are used in the sink model to determine the total potential of the natural environment to mitigate damage inflicted to humans by storms or tsunamis.

Representation

Data are represented as the presence/absence of mangroves.

Source

UNEP-WCMC World Atlas of Mangroves.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: UNEP World Atlas of Mangroves.
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Artificial coastal protection
page.title: Artificial coastal protection
page.description:
The presence of artificial coastal protection, which can reduce incoming wave energy.

Role in models

Seawalls and other engineered coastal protection can provide coastal flood mitigation, in combination with ecosystems or as a replacement of ecosystems in developed areas. Lacking data on coastal protection in Madagascar, we set artificial coastal protection is present near the port cities and absent elsewhere.

Representation

Data are represented as the presence/absence of artificial coastal protection.

Source

FTM.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: Foiben-Taosarintanin'i Madagasikara.
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Coral reef quality
page.title: Coral reef quality
page.description:
The presence of coral reefs, which can reduce incoming wave energy, and their health as proxied by degree of coral bleaching.

Role in models

Coral reefs, along with other vegetation and geomorphic features, are valuable in reducing wave energy that could otherwise inflict damage on coastal populations and property. When present, such features are used in the sink model to determine the total potential of the natural environment to mitigate damage inflicted to humans by storms or tsunamis. We assume that healthy, unbleached coral reefs are better able to absorb wave energy than bleached reefs, based on coral reef presence and bleaching data from UNEP-WCMC and ReefBase.

Representation

Data are represented as the presence/absence of coral reefs and their level of bleaching.

Source

UNEP-WCMC World Atlas of Coral Reefs.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: UNEP-WCMC World Atlas of Coral Reefs.
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Terrestrial vegetation
page.description:
Different vegetation types will dissipate wave energy at different rates.

Role in models

The type of terrestrial vegetation encountered on the coast is an important determinant of how much wave and wind energy can be absorbed by the ecosystem before it reaches humans assets and settlements. We assume that forests and wetlands are most effective in mitigating wave energy, followed by shrubland and herbaceous ecosystems, with other vegetation types (urban and agriculture) providing minimal protection. These data are used as input to the sink model, which estimates the total wave mitigation potential provided by natural features. The sink model, in turn, is used by the flow model to determine actual damage inflicted by storms and separate the influences of geomorphic wave mitigation (which would occur with or without ecosystems that provide wave mitigation) and the contribution of ecosystems in mitigating wave energy.

Representation

Data are categorical, derived from land cover classes.

Source

FTM.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: Foiben-Taosarintanin'i Madagasikara.
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Land and bathymetric slope
page.title: Land and bathymetric slope
page.description:
Slope influences the build-up or dissipation of wave energy.

Role in models

Slope data, calculated both on land and for the ocean floor, are used to model the behavoir of waves as they move toward land. In the ocean, steep slopes cause more rapid wave buildup while over land, steep slopes cause more rapid dissipation of wave energy.

Representation

The data are in physical units of degrees slope.

Source

Derived from NASA ETOPO1 Global Relief Model.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: Derived from NASA ETOPO1 Global Relief Model.
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Geomorphic protection
page.title: Geomorphic flood protection
page.description:
Wave energy dissipated by geomorphic features.

Role in models

The amount of the storm-generated wave energy that reaches the coast depends on several factors, including the geomorphology on land and underwater. This map is a probabilistic assessment of the total protection provided by geomorphic features including sea floor depth, slope, terrestrial elevation, and the presence of dunes. These data are used in the flow model to determine actual damage inflicted by storms and separate the influences of geomorphic wave mitigation (which would occur with or without ecosystems that provide wave mitigation) and the contribution of ecosystems in mitigating wave energy.

Representation

The data are in physical units of meters of wave energy dissipated.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Dunes
page.title: Dune presence
page.description:
The presence of sand dunes, which can reduce incoming wave energy.

Role in models

Dunes and bathymetric configuration account for the bulk of natural coastal protection in areas where mangroves and seagrass are scarce. These data are used as input to the sink model, which establishes the total protection potential determined by natural features. The sink model, The sink model, in turn, is used by the flow model to determine actual damage inflicted by storms and separate the influences of geomorphic wave mitigation (which would occur with or without ecosystems that provide wave mitigation) and the contribution of ecosystems in mitigating wave energy.

Representation

Data are represented as the presence/absence of dunes.

Source

FTM.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: Foiben-Taosarintanin'i Madagasikara.
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Potential Coastal Flood Regulation
page.title: Potential Coastal Flood Regulation
page.description:
Wave energy dissipated by ecosystems.

Role in models

his map is the probabilistic output of the *sink* model, which puts together all the potentially preventative features of the landscape into a single map. Each point of the map details the likely amount of wave energy that can be mitigated by such features. The flow model uses this map to determine whether each point can deplete the energy coming from the storm front, thereby reducing the total amount of damage that reaches users.

Representation

The data are in physical units of meters of wave energy dissipated.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Potential damage
page.title: Potentially damaging wave flow
page.description:
*Possible flow maps* represent the path that the carrier of the service would take if it was not intercepted by sinks. As such it considers source and use models and shows the maximum amount of flow. For provisioning services, this corresponds to the maximum potential benefit; for preventive services, the maximum potential damage.
This map shows the flow route of wave energy across the land and seascape in the absence of sinks. Therefore it computes the maximum damage that would happen if natural features did not intercept it, and provides a baseline that allows estimation of the actual value of those features.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Potential waves
page.title: Source of potentially damaging waves
page.description:
Even in the absence of sinks, not all of a source quantity actually has the ability to reach users, because of the route that an ecosystem service carrier moves across the landscape. Flow analysis allows us to identify which particular portion of the total source quantity is actually generating carriers that reach the users, independent of the existence of sinks but taking into account the result of use values, the structure of the landscape and the flow paths of the carrier, producing this *possible source map*. For provisioning services, this corresponds to the source of benefits that has the potential of being actually useful. For preventive services, this corresponds to the portion of the source field that could actually cause damage to people. The location and strength of sinks determines how much of the source actually reaches the users.
This map represents what specific sources of waves are capable of harming people or damaging property when accounting for flow paths but not sinks.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Potential damage
page.title: Potential wave damage
page.description:
*Possible use maps* show the locations of users on the landscape that can receive a benefit due to flow connections with a source of an ecosystem service carrier, but may or may not actually receive the carrier due to the action of sinks. For provisioning services, potential use identifies areas where it is physically possible for a benefit to be received. For preventive services, potential use identifies areas that may be damaged by a detrimental carrier if sinks do not prevent such damage.
This map shows people or property receiving damage when accounting for sources of wind or waves and their flow paths but not accounting for the action of sinks that reduce potential damage from wind or waves.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Actual waves
page.title: Actual wave flow
page.description:
The *actual flow density* map shows the flow paths that deliver actual services to humans. These are selected from the total flow density to only show these flow paths that are not depleted by sinks and actually reach users.
For provisioning services, these flow paths deliver valuable benefits to the users and the density is proportional to the value accrued. For preventive services, the flow paths show how much of the carrier reaches users, delivering actual damage.
In this specific case, the density of actual flows represents the wave energy that impacts people or property, after accounting for wave routing due to winds, geophysics, and natural features that deplete their magnitude.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Flood source
page.title: Flood damaging wave source
page.description:
The *actual source map* shows the portion of the source map that is relevant to the provision of a service after accounting for sinks and flow dynamics. For provisioning services, this is the amount and location of a benefit that actually provides benefits to the users. For preventive services, it shows where the actual damage came from. Source regions that provided a damaging carrier were neutralized by sinks are not shown.
This map shows the source of those waves that actually harm people or damage property when accounting for flow paths and sinks.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Actual mitigation
page.title: Utilized wave mitigation
page.description:
The *actual sink map* shows the portion of the sinks that actually contribute to depleting a service carrier given its flow patterns. For provisioning services, such sinks are responsible for reducing the benefits compared to their possible value. For preventive services, such sinks provide the actual service because they prevent a damaging carrier from reaching users.
This map shows the sinks that actively reduce wave energy, providing the benefit of reduced flood or wind damage for people.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Actual damage
page.title: Wave damage received
page.description:
The *actual use map* shows the level of use of a beneficial carrier for a provisioning service or damage caused by a detrimental carrier for a preventive service, for users located across the landscape.
This map shows actual damage received by people and property when accounting for source locations and strength of waves, the action of sinks, and flow paths.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Absorbed waves
page.title: Absorbed wave flow
page.description:
The *blocked flow map* shows the flow paths that could have delivered the service carrier to humans based on the flow routes and the source and user locations, but did not because of the action of sinks. These are selected from among all actual flows.
For provisioning services, these flow paths show the loss in possible flow of beneficial services to the users, and their density is proportional to the value lost. For preventive services, the flow paths show the amount of the total flow that was prevented by natural features from causing damage.
This map shows wave or wind energy that is absorbed by natural features prior to reaching human beneficiaries that could be damaged by wind or waves.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Mitigated waves
page.title: Mitigated wave source
page.description:
The *blocked source map* shows the part of the source map that had the possibility of reaching users given the location of the users and the flow dynamics, but was blocked from doing so because of the action of sinks. For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment but lost before it reaches the users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but was blocked by natural features.
This map shows the portion of coastal wave energy whose damage potential is reduced by the action of natural features.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Total benefit
page.title: Wave mitigation benefits accrued
page.description:
The *blocked use map* shows those users that would have been reached by the service carrier based only on the source and the flow dynamics, but were not reached because of the action of sinks. For provisioning services, the map shows possible value that has not been accrued to users because of sinks; for preventive services, it shows actual value accrued by users thanks to sink configuration.
For preventive services, therefore, this map is the ultimate quantification of value given the locations and quantity of users and natural sink features.
This map shows people or economically valuable assets who are spared from coastal flood or wind damage due to the flood or wind mitigating activity of natural features.
page.see-also: The coastal flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.
